awd_abstract_narration:
PI: Fregly, Benjamin J.
Proposal: 1805896

Stroke, Parkinson's disease, and osteoarthritis affect roughly 15% of the U.S. adult population and often impair walking ability, leading to an increased risk of serious health conditions and a decreased quality of life. Traditional approaches for assessing patient function and delivering rehabilitation prescriptions require that the patient make repeated visits to the clinic, which is expensive and time consuming for the patient, the clinician, and the health care system. Ideally, clinicians could gather quantitative information about patient walking function, as well as deliver rehabilitation prescriptions, when the patient is at home or in the community. Wireless inertial measurement units (IMUs), which are electronic devices that use accelerometers to measure linear acceleration (along a straight line) and gyroscopes to measure angular velocity (rotation), are already being explored to provide such capabilities. However, existing computational algorithms (problem solving instructions) that convert IMU measurements into joint angle measurements are inadequate to support an IMU-based motion measurement system that provides accurate joint motion measurements AND is so simple that patients, family members, or caregivers can use it reliably with no technical expertise. This project seeks to develop a novel computational algorithm that achieves these goals. The algorithm will achieve accuracy and simplicity by combining several unique computational approaches. The proposed project will 1) DEVELOP the necessary computational algorithm using preexisting motion capture data collected simultaneously, 2) EVALUATE the algorithm's ease of use and accuracy by having 10 healthy subjects collect their own IMU-based motion capture data, and 3) DEPLOY the algorithm on a Windows tablet or Mac laptop to demonstrate that it can be used for real-time feedback applications. If successful, this project could facilitate the development of effective remote monitoring and telerehabilitation methods that reduce the need for clinician time and patient office visits, decrease healthcare costs, and increase treatment effectiveness. For outreach, "at risk" students in a Houston middle school will interact with the technology firsthand by competing in an annual "Jump Off" competition held via the internet (Skype) with students in a sister middle school in Auckland, New Zealand.

The goal of this project is to develop a wireless user-friendly IMU-based motion measurement system that is so simple and easy to use that virtually any patient or caregiver can use it to measure full-body walking movements at home or in the community with little training. Such a system could be clinically beneficial for both remote assessment of patient function using logged data and remote delivery of rehabilitation prescriptions using real-time feedback. The core of the stem is a novel motion estimation algorithm that will work for data logging and real-time applications. The algorithm will require only 6 IMUs-- each foot, pelvis, torso and each wrist--to measure full-body walking kinematics easily and repeatably. The project will progress in three phases. Phase 1 will involve algorithm development.  The algorithm will be an expanded version of an unscented filter (UF) algorithm developed for studying an existing planar 6 DOF walking model.  The first task will be to make that model more general and flexible by adding more coordinates and extending it to 3D.  The algorithm will be tested using experimental walking data and data obtained from an existing 29 DOF walking model representative of real-life conditions.  Phase 2 will involve algorithm evaluation for off-line applications. To demonstrate that, with minimum training, individuals in any environment can collect their own kinematic walking data using the algorithm, 10 healthy subjects will collect their own IMU-based walking data while also wearing markers to enable simultaneous marker-based motion capture to validate results.  Phase 3 will involve algorithm deployment for real-time applications.  The computational speed of the algorithm when deployed on hardware for real-time applications will be evaluated.  A wireless IMU based motion feedback system, consisting of 6 wireless IMUs and a Windows (or Mac) tablet control unit with software for real-time calculation and display of joint angles during walking, will be developed.  To verify that the system meets the project's goals --ease of use, rapid calibration, and collection and display of calculated joint positions in real time, 3 additional subjects will perform real-time data collection on themselves without wearing markers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project sought to develop a new computational approach for measuring human movement using inertial measurement units (IMUs). Compared to traditional human movement measurement methods involving expensive optimal motion capture systems that can be used only in controlled laboratory environments, IMUs provide an inexpensive option for measuring human movement in any environment, including outdoors and under water. The ability to measure human movement in any environment would be valuable for developing new home-based approaches for rehabilitation training and assessment of patients with movement impairments (e.g., due to stroke, osteoarthritis, and Parkinson’s disease). While IMUs typically possess three types of measurement devices (a gyroscope for measuring three-dimensional rotational velocity, an accelerometer for measuring three-dimensional linear acceleration including the acceleration due to gravity, and a magnetometer for measuring the three-dimensional direction of the Earth’s magnetic field), we sought to develop our computational approach without using magnetometer data, which can be corrupted by the presence of metal in the measurement environment (e.g., in a building).

At the core of our computational approach is a lower body kinematic model with joint constraints. The motion equations provided by this model turn guesses for lower body joint angles, velocities, and accelerations into corresponding estimates of IMU gyroscope and accelerometer measurements. In this way, guesses for the motion of the model’s joints can be iterated until the best match is obtained with quantities derived from experimental IMU gyroscope and accelerometer measurements.

We initially sought to develop a computational approach that could measure ambulatory tasks such as walking, jogging, and jumping in real time and require data from IMUs placed on only the pelvis and feet (i.e.,. no IMUs placed on the thighs or lower legs). Real-time capability is desirable since it opens up the possibility of providing real-time feedback for patient training purposes, while omission of IMUs from the thighs and lower legs (i.e., “interior” IMUs) could simplify the measurement process and make it easier to perform at home. For the first three years of the project, our research efforts explored computational approaches that required a numerical integration process (as is common practice) to turn noisy experimental IMU gyroscope and accelerometer data into lower body joint angles, since an integration-based approach seemed necessary to achieve real-time performance. Lower body joint angles calculated from IMU data were assessed by comparing with lower body joint angles calculated from optical motion capture data. After extensive exploration, we eventually realized that numerical integration of noisy IMU data was producing significant errors in estimated lower body joint angles and preventing our computational approach from working.

In the final year of the project, we revamped out computational approach by eliminating numerical integration of noisy IMU data applied one time frame at a time and replacing it with numerical differentiation of guessed lower body joint angles applied over a wide window of time frames simultaneously. However, we made this change at the expense of real-time measurement capability and omission of interior IMUs. We formulated a nonlinear optimization problem to implement this new computational approach, and it worked extremely well for walking, jogging, and jumping using experimental IMU data with at least one IMU placed on each lower body segment. However, small out-of-plane rotations occurring at the hip and ankle were estimated less accurately than the large in-plane rotations occurring at the hip, knee, and ankle.

To address this problem, we then explored the inclusion of simple machine learning models to estimate lower body joint angles directly from experimental IMU data. We incorporated these machine learning models into our nonlinear optimization problem formulation, and they significantly improved our estimates of the small out-of-plane hip and ankle rotations. We have since submitted a provisional patent application and a journal manuscript on our final nonlinear optimization approach for estimating human body joint angles directly from noisy experimental IMU gyroscope and accelerometer data without performing any numerical integration. The accuracy of our new computational approach could facilitate the use of IMUs for performing remote assessment of patient movement function without requiring the patient to visit a specialized clinic or human movement laboratory. With additional modifications in the future, it may also be possible to create a real-time implementation of the same novel computational approach.
